title: NYT > World News

items.title: ‘We Buried Him and Kept Walking’: Children Die as Somalis Flee Hunger
items.description: The worst drought in four decades, and a sharp rise in food prices caused by the war in Ukraine, have left almost half of Somalia’s people facing acute food shortages.
items.author: Abdi Latif Dahir and Malin Fezehai

items.title: Rumbling Through Modern Jordan, a Railway From the Past
items.description: Once an ambitious project to unite the Middle East, the antique Hejaz Railway is a relic of that bygone dream before wars, borders and more advanced modes of transport rendered its services obsolete.
items.author: Ben Hubbard, Asmaa al-Omar and Laura Boushnak

items.title: McDonald’s Is Reinvented in Russia as the Economy Stumbles On
items.description: The reopening of the fast-food stores under Russian ownership (and with a new logo) illustrates the economy’s surprising resilience in the face of intense sanctions, though tough times lie ahead.
items.author: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

items.title: Newly United, French Left Hopes to Counter President in Upcoming Vote
items.description: Left-wing parties have joined forces ahead of France’s two-stage parliamentary elections, hoping to revive their fortunes and put a break on President Emmanuel Macron’s agenda.
items.author: Constant Méheut

items.title: Recording India’s Linguistic Riches as Leaders Push Hindi as Nation’s Tongue
items.description: Ganesh Devy has spent decades documenting India’s hundreds of distinct languages. Up next: a 12,000-year history of India he hopes will help counter the government’s Hindu-first campaign.
items.author: Sameer Yasir

items.title: Shortage of Artillery Ammunition Saps Ukrainian Frontline Morale
items.description: Shells for Soviet-era weapons are running short, and powerful Western weapons are not arriving fast enough to make up the difference, giving Russia a big advantage in artillery.
items.author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Andrew E. Kramer and Natalia Yermak

items.title: Jeanine Añez, Former Bolivian President, Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
items.description: The trial of Jeanine Añez, who took power after Evo Morales was ousted, has led to concerns about politicians’ use of the justice system to target opponents.
items.author: Megan Janetsky and María Silvia Trigo

items.title: For South Africa’s Leader, Being a Burglary Victim Spells Trouble
items.description: After a fortune in cash was stolen from President Cyril Ramaphosa’s farmhouse, he kept it secret. Now that word is out, critics ask what he was hiding.
items.author: John Eligon

items.title: Live Updates: Eastern Battles Tilt in Russia’s Favor as Attrition Wears on Ukraine
items.description: Although Moscow seemed to be slowly gaining ground, there were some indications it is struggling to govern occupied areas in southern Ukraine.
items.author: The New York Times

items.title: U.S. Warns China on Taiwan as Defense Officials Meet to Cool Tensions
items.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III accused Beijing of “provocative” activity near the disputed island after meeting with his Chinese counterpart.
items.author: Chris Buckley and Sui-Lee Wee

items.title: U.K. Officials Won’t Investigate Political Donation Flagged for Russian Origins
items.description: A bank alert had said a $630,225 Conservative Party donation originated in a Russian account. The authorities say there’s no evidence that a crime was committed.
items.author: Jane Bradley

items.title: Single Cigarettes in Canada Will Be Inscribed With Warning
items.description: Cigarette boxes and packaging in Canada are also expected to see an expanded list of health effects related to smoking.
items.author: Vjosa Isai

items.title: Pope Francis Postpones Trip to Africa, Citing Knee Problems
items.description: The postponement of the trip to the Democratic Republic of Congo and South Sudan comes as speculation swirls that the pontiff may be thinking of stepping down.
items.author: Elisabetta Povoledo

items.title: Reforms Are Imposed on U.N. Agency That Made Questionable Investments
items.description: After a New York Times report revealed unusual investments putting tens of millions of dollars at risk, the board of the U.N.’s Office for Project Services demanded major changes.
items.author: Farnaz Fassihi and David Fahrenthold

items.title: Protests Over Prophet Muhammad Comments Turn Deadly in India
items.description: Two young protesters were killed in eastern India on Friday amid demonstrations by Muslims across South Asia.
items.author: Emily Schmall and Suhasini Raj

items.title: A Caravan of Migrants Is Heading Toward the U.S. Border
items.description: Some 6,000 migrants, many of them from Venezuela, set off from southern Mexico last week as leaders from across the Americas met in Los Angeles to discuss issues including migration.
items.author: Oscar Lopez and Alejandro Cegarra

items.title: Traffic-Clogged North England Bitter Over Stalled Rail Plan
items.description: Transport problems are just one symptom of the economic neglect that has long hobbled the region, where growth, employment and health care mostly lag far behind the south.
items.author: Aina J. Khan

items.title: The Phone Booth of the Mind
items.description: Phone booths may be obsolete, but they still offer a good model for keeping our phones from taking over our lives.
items.author: Melissa Kirsch

items.title: ‘A Mass Invasion of Privacy’ but No Penalties for Tim Hortons
items.description: A scathing report by four privacy commissioners found that the coffee and doughnut chain collected data on customers’ daily lives.
items.author: Ian Austen

items.title: Biden Races to Expand Coalition Against Russia but Meets Resistance
items.description: Many Asian, African and Latin American nations are maintaining ties with Russia as the United States tries to isolate President Vladimir V. Putin and end the war in Ukraine.
items.author: Lara Jakes and Edward Wong

items.title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
items.author: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Emma Bubola

items.title: C.D.C. Dismisses Airborne Transmission of Monkeypox. Some Experts Disagree.
items.description: The virus “is not known to linger in the air,” agency officials said. But the research is far from definitive.
items.author: Apoorva Mandavilli

items.title: Behind Enemy Lines, Scouts Help Ukrainians Execute Deadly Strikes
items.description: A nascent insurgency made up of civilians or former soldiers provided information that aided Ukraine’s attack on two Russian bases, according to a senior Ukrainian military official.
items.author: Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora

items.title: Royal Shipwreck From 1682 Is Found Off the Coast of England
items.description: The Gloucester, which was carrying a future king of England when it ran aground, was found 15 years ago. Its discovery was revealed this week.
items.author: Christine Hauser and Derrick Bryson Taylor

items.title: Why the Jan. 6 Hearings Matter
items.description: Even if the Jan. 6 attack will not become a unifying moment for the country.
items.author: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick

items.title: Miami-Dade, San Juan and Honolulu Have Become Covid Hot Spots
items.description: “Covid-19 hasn’t disappeared as much as our patience for precautions has,” said one public health expert.
items.author: Johnny Diaz and Christine Chung

items.title: Trapped by Russian Forces, Ukrainians Waited a Month in a Basement
items.description: More than 300 Ukrainians, 77 of them children, were imprisoned in a dank and airless school basement for nearly a month. Ten of them died.
items.author: Valerie Hopkins and Nicole Tung

items.title: When Cockatoos Become Cocka-Too Much
items.description: The native Australian birds are charismatic and deeply destructive.

items.title: Your Friday Briefing
items.description: Russia and Ukraine are struggling to control “dead cities.”
items.author: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

items.title: Biden Faces Skepticism at Summit of the Americas
items.description: The U.S. president called for concrete commitments on several major issues, but other leaders said the United States is doing too little to meet the moment.
items.author: Michael D. Shear, Miriam Jordan and Anatoly Kurmanaev

items.title: U.S. and Latin American Countries Will Commit to Receive More Migrants
items.description: A joint declaration is expected to be issued Friday meant to address surging migration rates that have affected nations throughout the region.
items.author: Miriam Jordan

items.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Crucial Moment in the Ukraine War
items.description: Plus the U.S. begins Jan. 6 hearings and Chinese pilots provoke U.S. allies.
items.author: Amelia Nierenberg

items.title: ‘Dead Cities’ Become the Flashpoint for the Fierce War in the East
items.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky has framed the battle in Sievierodonetsk as pivotal to the broader fight for the Donbas. Amid relentless Russian attacks, Ukraine holds on and waits for Western weapons.
items.author: Andrew E. Kramer and Ivor Prickett

items.title: Iran Begins to Dismantle Nuclear Program Cameras After Western Criticism
items.description: At a moment when experts say Iran is, again, on the verge of possessing enough fuel for a bomb, the dismantling of U.N. cameras was a sign of worsening prospects for the 2015 deal.
items.author: Isabella Kwai

items.title: Biden and Bolsonaro Meet for First Time at Summit
items.description: President Jair Bolsonaro addressed concerns about Brazil’s upcoming election, saying he came to power democratically and would leave office the same way.
items.author: Jack Nicas and Michael D. Shear

items.title: Foreign Fighters Sentenced to Death in Russia-Held Eastern Ukraine
items.description: Legal experts said the death sentences appeared calculated to discourage foreign volunteers from joining Ukraine’s military.
items.author: Dan Bilefsky and Valerie Hopkins

items.title: Dmitry Kovtun, Accused Killer of Russian Dissident, Dies at 56
items.description: He and another ex-spy were found by British authorities to have served polonium-laced tea in London to an intelligence agent who had defected.
items.author: Sam Roberts

items.title: U.S. Accelerated Expulsions of Haitian Migrants in May
items.description: The uptick has rekindled criticism that the Biden administration treats Black migrants differently than others, an allegation it denies.
items.author: Eileen Sullivan

items.title: Putin Compares Himself to Peter the Great, the Famous Czar
items.description: Vladimir Putin likened his goals in Ukraine to the conquests of Peter the Great.
items.author: Anton Troianovski

items.title: Naftali Bennett, Israel’s Prime Minister, Visits U.A.E.
items.description: The trip by Naftali Bennett, the Israeli leader, burnishes his foreign policy credentials and provides some distraction from his domestic political troubles.
items.author: Isabel Kershner

items.title: The Best Books to Read on Disinformation: Its History, Techniques and Effects
items.description: The phenomenon has undermined our trust in electoral systems, in vaccines — and in what happened at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6. Here are books on its history, techniques and effects.
items.author: Richard Stengel

items.title: Russia Prosecuting 1,100 Captured Ukrainian Soldiers
items.description: Announcing the invasion in February, Vladimir Putin said Ukrainians would be prosecuted for “blood crimes.” Moscow is now making good on that vow.
items.author: Ivan Nechepurenko

items.title: The Racist Researcher Cited in the Buffalo Gunman’s Manifesto
items.description: The work of Michael Woodley, a Briton who was cited by the teenager who killed 10 Black people at a supermarket in Buffalo, included pseudoscientific theories that have been used to justify racism.
items.author: Monika Pronczuk and Koba Ryckewaert

items.title: Tourist Damages Rome’s Spanish Steps by Pushing a Scooter Down Them
items.description: An American woman and her companion caused $27,000 in damage to the landmark, officials said. They were fined and have been barred from the site for six months.
items.author: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Emma Bubola

items.title: German Brewers Face ‘Unprecedented’ Beer Bottle Shortage
items.description: A nation of beer lovers is facing a shortage of bottles, partly because of the war in Ukraine. Breweries are looking to drinkers for a rescue.
items.author: Melissa Eddy

items.title: 2 Officials in Vietnam Are Arrested in Virus Test Kit Scandal
items.description: The health minister and the mayor of Hanoi were removed from their posts in a scandal that has led to charges against dozens of officials.
items.author: Richard C. Paddock and Vo Kieu Bao Uyen

items.title: Covid and Race
items.description: The death rate for white Americans has recently exceeded the rates for Black, Latino and Asian Americans.
items.author: David Leonhardt

items.title: Chinese Pilots Sent a Message. American Allies Said They Went Too Far.
items.description: Australia and Canada said Chinese jets harassed their military planes, though Beijing says it was defending its security. A mishap over Pacific waters could have ominous repercussions.
items.author: Austin Ramzy

items.title: A Radical Collective Takes Over One of the World’s Biggest Art Shows
items.description: Ruangrupa, an Indonesian group of collaborators, turns social experiences into art. How will they leave their mark on Documenta, which unfolds over 100 days?
items.author: Samanth Subramanian

items.title: White House Outlines Covid Vaccine Plan for Children Under 5
items.description: Vaccine deliveries to U.S. states are contingent on the Food and Drug Administration authorizing pediatric doses, a step that could occur as soon as next week.
items.author: Noah Weiland

items.title: Biden Administration to Set Rules of the Road for Charging Electric Vehicles
items.description: Proposed regulations would require charging stations built with federal dollars to be located no more than 50 miles apart.
items.author: Lisa Friedman

items.title: At Least 7 Killed in Explosion and Fire in Daegu, South Korea
items.description: A man in his 50s was suspected of setting off the explosion that started the blaze at a law office in the city of Daegu, the police said. He is believed to have died in the fire.
items.author: John Yoon, Jin Yu Young and Tiffany May

items.title: Your Thursday Briefing
items.description: Russia cements its grip on southern Ukraine.
items.author: Natasha Frost

items.title: Russia Has Filled Ukrainian Water Canal to Crimea
items.description: Ukraine blocked a freshwater to canal to the Crimean Peninsula after Russia occupied it 2014. Moscow has fully restored the flow, easing its path to a “land bridge” with Russia, images show.
items.author: Anton Troianovski and Malachy Browne

items.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia’s Land Bridge
items.description: Moscow is trying to deepen its hold on occupied Ukrainian territory in the south.
items.author: Amelia Nierenberg

items.title: Russia Is Racing to Cement Its Control in Southern Ukraine
items.description: The Kremlin says it has rebuilt rail and road links to Crimea, while appointing proxy officials in an effort to create facts on the ground.
items.author: Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Anton Troianovski and Michael Levenson

items.title: A Wider Lens on the MeToo Backlash: Who Pays for Societal Change?
items.description: The same fundamentals apply to patriarchal systems, whether in Hollywood or India: Threats to men’s status can provoke broader resistance than you might think.
items.author: Amanda Taub
